title: BitLayer
description: BitLayer is building towards a validia chain on top of Bitcoin. Its current implementation is run by a network of 21, federated validators securing the network. It supports an EVM execution environment with plans to support other VMs. In its docs, BitLayer states that it will use an offchain data availability solution in its future mainnet releases. Its roadmap sees it adding support for a BitVM-style bridge, but currently, the bridge is managed by various multi-sig wallets.

content.title: BitLayer's mainnet v1 is a sidechain
content.content: BitLayer is building towards a validia chain on top of Bitcoin. Its current implementation is run by a network of 21, federated validators securing the network. It supports an EVM execution environment with plans to support other VMs. In its docs, BitLayer states that it will use an offchain data availability solution in its future mainnet releases. Its roadmap sees it adding support for a BitVM-style bridge, but currently, the bridge is managed by various multi-sig wallets.

content.title: Users trust a federated multi-sig and upgradeable contracts with the custody of their BTC
content.content: We are currently reviewing the exact implementation of BitLayer's two-way peg with Bitcoin. It has been publicly acknowledge by the team that the current implementation is a federated multi-sig. BTC users will deposit their BTC into a Bitcoin multi-sig wallet that initiates an unlock transfer from a vault on the BitLayer chain. EVM users can deposit wBTC into BitLayer from their EVM wallet. Both bridge contracts, on BitLayer, are upgradeable by an admin.

content.title: Data is stored offchain
content.content: BitLayer does not currently use Bitcoin for data availability. We are currently reviewing the specific parties responsible for data availability.

content.title: Blocks are produced by a permissioned validator set
content.content: BitLayer blocks are currently produced by a permissioned validator set. Information on how blocks are produced is limited, but it seems that BitLayer blocks are evenly distributed, and produced in order, by its validator set

content.title: No onchain enforcement of BitLayer state transitions
content.content: There is no onchain enforcement of BitLayer state transitions on Bitcoin.

content.title: BitVM being researched
content.content: BitLayer is currently researching how BitVM can improve trust assumptions related to its two-way peg with Bitcoin. The BitLayer team has an open repository of research related to BitVM. BitLayer’s documentation site states that the BitVM implementation will be federated.

content.title: BTR token issued, but validators are not required to stake BTR
content.content: None of the validators in BitLayer’s validator set are staking its native token, BTR. Currently the BTR supply is 1B and is dispersed across 6 addresses. It is unknown if BitLayer will use this token to incentivize its current set of validators, or other future operators.

content.title: Offchain DA on roadmap
content.content: BitLayer will not use Bitcoin for data availability long-term. This means that it will be a validia chain.

content.title: Ethereum Virtual Machine
content.content: BitLayer uses an EVM-compatible virtual machine. The Ethereum Virtual Machine is software responsible for smart contract execution for a number of blockchains, namely the Ethereum Network. It uses Solidity/Vyper as its code and is the dominant environment for smart contract execution in the cryptocurrency ecosystem. BitLayer is EVM-compatible, which means that a developer from Ethereum would have less difficulty deploying their applications on BitLayer compared to other execution environments.

content.title: Faster block times
content.content: BitLayer is currently producing blocks every two seconds which provides a better user experience than using the Bitcoin mainchain.

content.title: EVM-based applications
content.content: The potential use cases for BitLayer are similar to that of other EVM-based sidechains. Developers can deploy smart contracts that enable applications like borrowing and lending protocols, stablecoins, NFTs, and more. The primary, proposed use case for BitLayer is to act as an application layer for Bitcoin.

content.title: BitLayer is run by a permissioned validator set
content.content: BitLayer is currently run by 21 federated validators securing the network. The operators of these validators are unknown. Although these validators would presumably stake BitLayer's native token, BTR, to secure the network, none of the active validator addresses currently hold any BTR tokens. These nodes are presumably responsible for data availability, block production and finalizing the state of the sidechain.

content.title: BTC users must withdraw to Ethereum L1 before withdrawing to Bitcoin
content.content: Withdrawals from BitLayer to Bitcoin are permitted by a centralized operator and take 3-7 days to process.

content.title: Portions of code is open-source
content.content: Some of the code related to the BitLayer project is open-source.
